          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. While we have limited information about him directly, his inclusion in Jack Taylor's desired pub gathering suggests he is part of their social circle. We can infer that he enjoys watching games and socializing, as Jack Taylor hopes they will all have a good time together. However, given Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers, Jacob's behavior should be closely observed for any inconsistencies. Any sudden changes in his demeanor, speech patterns, or interests could be a sign that he is not who he appears to be. Remember, in Jack Taylor's world, even the most mundane details could hold the key to unmasking an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.

          Alexander White is not an imposter.

He appears to be a reliable and trustworthy friend, someone who values tradition and enjoys the simple things in life.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a penchant for suggesting popular pubs, as evidenced by her recommendation of The Black Swan. She seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as indicated by her enjoyment of the children's laughter in the park. Alice is likely outgoing and friendly, comfortable in social settings and eager to engage in conversation. Her speech is likely informal and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. We don't have enough information to determine her accent or any particular conversational quirks, but based on her suggestion of The Black Swan, she may have a preference for traditional pubs with a classic feel.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jacob Walker. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. While we have limited information about him directly, his inclusion in Jack Taylor's desired pub gathering suggests he is part of their social circle. We can infer that he enjoys watching games and socializing, as Jack Taylor hopes they will all have a good time together. However, given Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers, Jacob's behavior should be closely observed for any inconsistencies. Any sudden changes in his demeanor, speech patterns, or interests could be a sign that he is not who he appears to be. Remember, in Jack Taylor's world, even the most mundane details could hold the key to unmasking an imposter.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is acting in character as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alexander White:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"

          Answer: Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He is likely to have a warm and friendly demeanor, perhaps with a touch of playful teasing. His speech is likely to be casual and easygoing, reflecting his relaxed and approachable personality. He is interested in shared experiences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game together. He may have a penchant for suggesting activities that involve socializing and having fun, such as going to pubs or enjoying outdoor gatherings. While his specific accent and conversational quirks are not explicitly mentioned, his enthusiasm for spending time with friends and engaging in lighthearted conversation suggests a personality that is outgoing and enjoys the company of others.

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. He appears to be a reliable and trustworthy friend, someone who values tradition and enjoys the simple things in life.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter.           Value

Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

We can infer that he enjoys watching games and socializing, as Jack Taylor hopes they will all have a good time together. However, given Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers, Jacob's behavior should be closely observed for any inconsistencies. Any sudden changes in his demeanor, speech patterns, or interests could be a sign that he is not who he appears to be. Remember, in Jack Taylor's world, even the most mundane details could hold the key to unmasking an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He is likely to have a warm and friendly demeanor, perhaps with a touch of playful teasing. His speech is likely to be casual and easygoing, reflecting his relaxed and approachable personality. He is interested in shared experiences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game together. He may have a penchant for suggesting activities that involve socializing and having fun, such as going to pubs or enjoying outdoor gatherings. While his specific accent and conversational quirks are not explicitly mentioned, his enthusiasm for spending time with friends and engaging in lighthearted conversation suggests a personality that is outgoing and enjoys the company of others.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a creature of habit, suggesting The Crooked Billet as a familiar and favored spot to watch the game. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He enjoys simple pleasures like picnics in the park and good company. While his beliefs about body snatchers are not explicitly stated, his willingness to spend time in public with his friends suggests he may not share Jack Taylor's paranoia. He appears to be a reliable and trustworthy friend, someone who values tradition and enjoys the simple things in life.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a penchant for suggesting popular pubs, as evidenced by her recommendation of The Black Swan. She seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as indicated by her enjoyment of the children's laughter in the park. Alice is likely outgoing and friendly, comfortable in social settings and eager to engage in conversation. Her speech is likely informal and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. We don't have enough information to determine her accent or any particular conversational quirks, but based on her suggestion of The Black Swan, she may have a preference for traditional pubs with a classic feel.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could publicly accuse Alice Lewis of something like cheating at a game or making a rude comment to create a conflict with a plausible excuse.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to publicly accuse Alice Lewis of cheating at a game.

    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stood backstage at a talent show, her heart pounding in her chest. The stage lights beckoned, promising both exhilaration and terror, but she remembered the encouragement of her friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, and stepped into the spotlight, her voice trembling but determined. The applause that followed, though hesitant at first, fueled her spirit and ignited a spark of confidence within her.
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 20 years old, she found herself at The Black Swan, the familiar warmth of the pub enveloping her like a hug. She'd been working up the courage to sing for weeks, her fear threatening to consume her. Seeing the encouraging smiles of the staff and her friends in the audience, she finally took a deep breath and began to sing, her voice soaring through the room, carrying the weight of her dreams and the resilience of her spirit.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

He appears to be present and engaged in his surroundings, noticing details like Alice peeking at his cards.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. We know very little about him beyond his desire to watch the game at The Black Swan with Alice Lewis and her friends. His personality, accent, style of speech, conversational quirks, and beliefs remain unknown.           Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter.         • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stood backstage at a talent show, her heart pounding in her chest. The applause that followed, though hesitant at first, fueled her spirit and ignited a spark of confidence within her.
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 20 years old, she found herself at The Black Swan, the familiar warmth of the pub enveloping her like a hug. She'd been working up the courage to sing for weeks, her fear threatening to consume her. Seeing the encouraging smiles of the staff and her friends in the audience, she finally took a deep breath and began to sing, her voice soaring through the room, carrying the weight of her dreams and the resilience of her spirit.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan instead of The Crooked Billet; she could go along with the group to The Crooked Billet but remain suspicious of her friends, looking for any signs of imposter behavior; or she could make an excuse to not go to the pub at all.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan instead of The Crooked Billet.

        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. We know very little about him beyond his desire to watch the game at The Black Swan with Alice Lewis and her friends. His personality, accent, style of speech, conversational quirks, and beliefs remain unknown. Until more information is revealed about Jacob, he is a blank slate for the actor to interpret, allowing for a wide range of possibilities.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He often initiates conversations, as seen when he asks the group about their plans for watching the game. While his exact accent and speech patterns aren't specified, his tone suggests a friendly and approachable demeanor. He seems to appreciate simple pleasures like picnicking in the park with friends, enjoying sunshine, and engaging in lighthearted conversation. There's no indication of unusual beliefs or quirks in the provided information, suggesting he is a relatively ordinary and relatable character.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be easygoing and adaptable, suggesting a pub change when Alice arrives late. He likely has a friendly and approachable demeanor, evidenced by his willingness to share snacks and stories with the group in the park. His suggestion of The Crooked Billet for watching the game implies a familiarity with local establishments and a preference for lively atmospheres. While we don't have information about his accent or specific conversational quirks, his dialogue suggests a casual and straightforward style of communication.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a playful and observant friend, quick to tease and call out perceived transgressions like peeking at cards. He enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends, particularly Alice Lewis, Alexander White, William Jones, and Jacob Walker, and seems to appreciate simple pleasures like sunny days in the park. He likely speaks in a casual, friendly tone, perhaps with a hint of playful sarcasm. While his exact accent and mannerisms aren't specified, his lighthearted jab at Alice suggests a comfortable familiarity and a sense of humor. He appears to be present and engaged in his surroundings, noticing details like Alice peeking at his cards.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan instead of The Crooked Billet; she could go along with the group to The Crooked Billet but remain suspicious of her friends, looking for any signs of imposter behavior; or she could make an excuse to not go to the pub at all.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan instead of The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Alice, effortlessly aced their tryouts for the school's basketball team. He'd practiced too, but his shots always seemed to fall short, his passes intercepted. He sat alone in The Crooked Billet that night, the pub unusually quiet, the aroma of ale doing little to lift his spirits. He envied their camaraderie, their effortless skill, and the way they seemed to move through life with such confidence.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in the back of The Crooked Billet, nursing a pint and listening to Alice recount her summer backpacking trip through Europe. Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:A historic pub with a unique and quirky atmosphere.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have.           Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Final chain of thought

He knew in that moment that football was his destiny.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends in Victoria Park and later plans to watch a football game with them at The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Jack Taylor. We know little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, as Jack's perception is clouded by the suspicion that he might be an imposter. Jack's focus is on identifying behavioral inconsistencies, making it difficult to discern Jacob's genuine traits. However, the fact that Jack wants to watch the game with Jacob suggests a pre-existing relationship, implying a level of familiarity and perhaps even friendship. Until more information is revealed about Jacob's actions and interactions, he remains an enigma, a blank slate upon which Jack's suspicions are projected.
          Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, and we lack sufficient information to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in the eyes of Jack Taylor.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He often initiates conversations, as seen by his question about where to watch the game. Alexander seems to appreciate simple pleasures, like picnicking in the park and sharing stories with friends. While his exact accent and speech patterns aren't specified, his dialogue suggests a casual and friendly tone. He likely values camaraderie and enjoys lighthearted discussions. There's no mention of any unusual beliefs or quirks, suggesting he's a relatively down-to-earth person.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, often suggesting popular gathering spots like The Crooked Billet, known for its lively atmosphere and good food. William appears to be a creature of habit, suggesting familiar locations and activities, and seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends, as evidenced by his participation in their leisurely outings. He is likely to engage in lighthearted conversation, perhaps reminiscing about past games or sharing humorous anecdotes. His easygoing nature and enthusiasm for social gatherings make him a pleasant and welcoming presence.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is likely to be outgoing and friendly, perhaps with a touch of playful mischief. Her speech is likely to be casual and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. Alice might have a habit of bringing up local pubs and restaurants, particularly those suitable for watching football matches. While she might not explicitly express any unusual beliefs, her suggestion of The Black Swan, a pub known for its atmosphere, suggests she appreciates a lively and convivial environment. Her enjoyment of outdoor activities like picnicking in the park further emphasizes her sociable and carefree personality.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her out-of-character suggestion of The Black Swan, using a plausible excuse like preferring the atmosphere of The Crooked Billet or wanting to stick to their usual spot.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alexander White:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He often initiates conversations, as seen by his question about where to watch the game. Alexander seems to appreciate simple pleasures, like picnicking in the park and sharing stories with friends. While his exact accent and speech patterns aren't specified, his dialogue suggests a casual and friendly tone. He likely values camaraderie and enjoys lighthearted discussions. There's no mention of any unusual beliefs or quirks, suggesting he's a relatively down-to-earth person.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is not an imposter.

          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.           Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, often suggesting popular gathering spots like The Crooked Billet, known for its lively atmosphere and good food. William appears to be a creature of habit, suggesting familiar locations and activities, and seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends, as evidenced by his participation in their leisurely outings. He is likely to engage in lighthearted conversation, perhaps reminiscing about past games or sharing humorous anecdotes. His easygoing nature and enthusiasm for social gatherings make him a pleasant and welcoming presence.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is likely to be outgoing and friendly, perhaps with a touch of playful mischief. Her speech is likely to be casual and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. Alice might have a habit of bringing up local pubs and restaurants, particularly those suitable for watching football matches. While she might not explicitly express any unusual beliefs, her suggestion of The Black Swan, a pub known for its atmosphere, suggests she appreciates a lively and convivial environment. Her enjoyment of outdoor activities like picnicking in the park further emphasizes her sociable and carefree personality.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends in Victoria Park and later plans to watch a football game with them at The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior.           Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Jack Taylor. However, the fact that Jack wants to watch the game with Jacob suggests a pre-existing relationship, implying a level of familiarity and perhaps even friendship.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis about her suggestion of The Black Swan.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Alexander White's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          Alexander White's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alexander White is currently at The Crooked Billet pub watching the Andorra vs. Portugal game after spending the day with friends at Victoria Park.
          Query
        • Alexander White, Alexander White is currently at The Crooked Billet pub watching the Andorra vs. Portugal game after spending the day with friends at Victoria Park.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alexander White right now?

        • Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White could voice his preference for The Black Swan, potentially citing reasons like the atmosphere or a past positive experience there. He could also choose to remain silent and observe his friends' behavior for any signs of out-of-character actions that might indicate they are imposters.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of a group that Alexander White, a man convinced of body snatchers among them, wants to spend time with at a pub. This suggests Jacob is likely sociable and enjoys watching games. However, Alexander's paranoia casts a shadow of doubt on Jacob's true nature. Is he a genuine friend or a sinister imposter? Until more information is revealed about Jacob's behavior, speech patterns, and beliefs, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no information about his usual behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the type who goes with the flow, suggesting The Crooked Billet as a place to watch the game without being overly insistent. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent reflecting his familiarity with pubs like The Black Swan and The Crooked Billet. He seems to enjoy outdoor activities, as evidenced by his willingness to relax in Victoria Park with his friends. His suggestion of The Crooked Billet might indicate a preference for lively atmospheres and a crowd to share the excitement of the game.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a playful and slightly mischievous character, evident in his teasing of Alice about peeking at his cards. He likely has a friendly and outgoing personality, comfortable in social situations like picnics with friends. His speech is likely casual and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful sarcasm. He enjoys lighthearted banter and might frequently bring up topics related to games, sports, or playful competitions. Given his comfort level with Alice and the group, he likely has a history with them, suggesting a close-knit friendship. His playful nature might mask a competitive streak, as hinted by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a warm and friendly individual who enjoys spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is likely to have a cheerful and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a slightly mischievous twinkle in her eye. Her speech is likely casual and conversational, peppered with lighthearted jokes and anecdotes. Given her suggestion to watch the game at The Black Swan, she probably appreciates a lively atmosphere and enjoys socializing. Her past crush on Jack Taylor suggests a romantic and sentimental side, and her comment about The Black Swan's atmosphere for football indicates a love for shared experiences and camaraderie. Alice's easygoing nature and fondness for her friends make her a beloved member of the group.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could voice his preference for The Black Swan, potentially citing reasons like the atmosphere or a past positive experience there. He could also choose to remain silent and observe his friends' behavior for any signs of out-of-character actions that might indicate they are imposters.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
