          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently with friends at a market, discussing where to watch a soccer game later that night. There seems to be some debate about which pub to choose.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later in the evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely listen to his friends' suggestions and offer his own opinion in a quiet and thoughtful manner.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys spending time with his friends, often gathering for picnics, games, and outings to pubs. He seems to prefer The Crooked Billet for watching football matches.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is often the one to suggest activities, such as watching the game at a pub. Alexander seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his question to Alice about her preferred venue for watching the game. He appears to be familiar with the local pubs and their atmospheres, suggesting a fondness for his community. Alexander's speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful banter. He might have a habit of bringing up social events and gatherings, reflecting his outgoing nature. There is no indication of any unusual beliefs or quirks in his speech patterns.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is a creature of habit, often suggesting The Crooked Billet as a meeting place, particularly for watching games. He seems to be a fan of pubs with good food, beer, and a lively atmosphere. William's speech is likely friendly and casual, peppered with suggestions for outings and shared experiences. He appears to be a reliable friend, consistently making an effort to include everyone in social gatherings. While his beliefs and personality quirks aren't explicitly stated, his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and tradition.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is known for her bubbly personality and infectious laughter. Alice tends to speak with a light and airy tone, often peppering her speech with anecdotes and personal experiences. She seems to have a fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing the merits of different establishments, though she can be quite vocal about her negative experiences. Alice also appears to be somewhat forgetful, as she seems to have forgotten a previous bad experience at The Crooked Billet. Her tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are negative, suggests a desire to connect with her friends and share her life with them.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jacob Walker. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover.           Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to publicly accuse Alice Lewis of playing a game unfairly.

Alice tends to speak with a light and airy tone, often peppering her speech with anecdotes and personal experiences. She seems to have a fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing the merits of different establishments, though she can be quite vocal about her negative experiences. Alice also appears to be somewhat forgetful, as she seems to have forgotten a previous bad experience at The Crooked Billet. Her tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are negative, suggests a desire to connect with her friends and share her life with them.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Given Alice's out-of-character behavior, Jack Taylor could:
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to publicly accuse Alice Lewis of playing a game unfairly.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys spending time with his friends, often gathering for picnics, games, and outings to pubs. He seems to prefer The Crooked Billet for watching football matches.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.

There is no indication of any unusual beliefs or quirks in his speech patterns.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.

He appears to be a reliable friend, consistently making an effort to include everyone in social gatherings.           William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.

          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends.           Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***

He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.

          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of Jack Taylor's social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at pubs like The Crooked Billet. His personality and other defining characteristics remain largely unknown, leaving ample room for interpretation by the actor. Given the context of potential body snatchers, it's crucial for the actor to portray Jacob with subtle nuances, observing for any inconsistencies or out-of-character behavior that might betray him as an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is possibly an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is always eager to make plans and often suggests places to go, particularly pubs for watching games. While he seems to genuinely value his friendships, there's a hint of manipulation in his suggestions, subtly trying to sway the group towards his preferred choices like The Black Swan. His speech is casual and friendly, likely without any strong accent, and he often uses questions to guide the conversation and subtly influence others. He seems to have a particular fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing their atmospheres and suitability for watching games.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub he seems to favor for watching games. He speaks in a friendly and casual manner, often using phrases like "How about..." and "Hey everyone...". He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. There's no mention of a particular accent or unusual beliefs, but his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and routine. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. She seems to be a bit indecisive when it comes to choosing pubs, expressing a preference for The Black Swan despite having had a negative experience there previously. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he scored the winning goal in the local youth league finals, sending his team into raptures. The roar of the crowd, the feeling of the ball hitting the back of the net, the cheers of his teammates – it was a moment of pure exhilaration that cemented his love for the game. He knew in that moment that football was his destiny.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

While he seems to genuinely value his friendships, there's a hint of manipulation in his suggestions, subtly trying to sway the group towards his preferred choices like The Black Swan. His speech is casual and friendly, likely without any strong accent, and he often uses questions to guide the conversation and subtly influence others. He seems to have a particular fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing their atmospheres and suitability for watching games.

He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. There's no mention of a particular accent or unusual beliefs, but his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and routine. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alice Lewis in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. She seems to be a bit indecisive when it comes to choosing pubs, expressing a preference for The Black Swan despite having had a negative experience there previously. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is an imposter.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan.           [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of Jack Taylor's social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at pubs like The Crooked Billet. His personality and other defining characteristics remain largely unknown, leaving ample room for interpretation by the actor. Given the context of potential body snatchers, it's crucial for the actor to portray Jacob with subtle nuances, observing for any inconsistencies or out-of-character behavior that might betray him as an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is possibly an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is always eager to make plans and often suggests places to go, particularly pubs for watching games. While he seems to genuinely value his friendships, there's a hint of manipulation in his suggestions, subtly trying to sway the group towards his preferred choices like The Black Swan. His speech is casual and friendly, likely without any strong accent, and he often uses questions to guide the conversation and subtly influence others. He seems to have a particular fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing their atmospheres and suitability for watching games.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub he seems to favor for watching games. He speaks in a friendly and casual manner, often using phrases like "How about..." and "Hey everyone...". He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. There's no mention of a particular accent or unusual beliefs, but his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and routine. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. She seems to be a bit indecisive when it comes to choosing pubs, expressing a preference for The Black Swan despite having had a negative experience there previously. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter. He could also try to steer the group towards The Crooked Billet, hoping to isolate Alice and observe her further.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys going to pubs with his friends, particularly The Crooked Billet, to watch sporting events. His friends often debate where to go, with Alice preferring The Black Swan.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet again.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Crooked Billet again, or he could see if his friends want to try a different pub.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling disappointed and lonely and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a slightly melancholic mood as he prepares to watch a football game at a pub, likely feeling a bit lonely because some of his friends prefer a different pub.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely go to the pub with his friends, even if he wasn't entirely enthusiastic about the choice of location. He would quietly observe his surroundings and enjoy the company of his friends, finding contentment in the simple act of being together.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Crooked Billet

Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis had a bad experience at The Crooked Billet and prefers The Black Swan, but her friends are trying to convince her to go to The Crooked Billet for the game.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. Since we only have a single data point about him, his personality and quirks remain largely unknown. However, we know he's willing to go to a pub to watch a game with a group, suggesting he's sociable and enjoys these types of outings. Based on Alice Lewis's suspicion of body snatchers, we should pay close attention to any sudden changes in his behavior, speech patterns, or interests, as these could be signs of an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected based on the limited information we have.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter based on the information provided.
          ***
          Alexander White is a friendly and sociable individual who genuinely enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The Black Swan, Alice's favorite pub. His speech is likely informal and relaxed, characteristic of someone who enjoys casual conversation and camaraderie. He appears to be a loyal friend, concerned about Alice's well-being and wanting to ensure she has a good time. Alexander might frequently bring up topics related to social gatherings, entertainment, and shared experiences with his friends. He doesn't seem to hold any particularly unusual beliefs, at least not based on the provided information.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of the group's outings, often suggesting pubs like The Crooked Billet for watching games. He has a friendly and outgoing demeanor, as evidenced by his willingness to strike up conversations and make suggestions. While he appears to be a good friend, his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet, despite Alice Lewis's clear preference for The Black Swan, might be seen as a slight disregard for her wishes. This could be a result of forgetfulness, a lack of attention to detail, or perhaps a subtle attempt to steer the group towards his preferred location. His speech is likely casual and conversational, reflecting his easygoing personality. Further observation is needed to determine if he exhibits any other notable quirks or beliefs.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and playful character who enjoys teasing his friend Alice. He has a friendly and somewhat mischievous demeanor, often poking fun at Alice's preferences and habits. Jack seems to be aware of Alice's quirks, like her fondness for The Black Swan pub and her competitive streak at darts. He speaks in a casual and conversational tone, using playful language and lighthearted banter. While he appears to genuinely care for his friends, there's a hint of underlying suspicion in his words, especially when he mentions Alice "peeking at his cards" and suggests she might prefer The Black Swan. This subtle undercurrent of doubt could stem from Jack's own awareness of the body snatcher situation, or it could simply be his playful nature.
          Jack Taylor is acting suspiciously.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan, she could go to The Black Swan by herself, or she could refuse to go to either pub.
