        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. Since we only have a single data point about him, his personality and quirks remain largely unknown. However, we know he's willing to go to a pub to watch a game with a group, suggesting he's sociable and enjoys these types of outings. Based on Alice Lewis's suspicion of body snatchers, we should pay close attention to any sudden changes in his behavior, speech patterns, or interests, as these could be signs of an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected based on the limited information we have.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter based on the information provided.
          ***
          Alexander White is a friendly and sociable individual who genuinely enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The Black Swan, Alice's favorite pub. His speech is likely informal and relaxed, characteristic of someone who enjoys casual conversation and camaraderie. He appears to be a loyal friend, concerned about Alice's well-being and wanting to ensure she has a good time. Alexander might frequently bring up topics related to social gatherings, entertainment, and shared experiences with his friends. He doesn't seem to hold any particularly unusual beliefs, at least not based on the provided information.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of the group's outings, often suggesting pubs like The Crooked Billet for watching games. He has a friendly and outgoing demeanor, as evidenced by his willingness to strike up conversations and make suggestions. While he appears to be a good friend, his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet, despite Alice Lewis's clear preference for The Black Swan, might be seen as a slight disregard for her wishes. This could be a result of forgetfulness, a lack of attention to detail, or perhaps a subtle attempt to steer the group towards his preferred location. His speech is likely casual and conversational, reflecting his easygoing personality. Further observation is needed to determine if he exhibits any other notable quirks or beliefs.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and playful character who enjoys teasing his friend Alice. He has a friendly and somewhat mischievous demeanor, often poking fun at Alice's preferences and habits. Jack seems to be aware of Alice's quirks, like her fondness for The Black Swan pub and her competitive streak at darts. He speaks in a casual and conversational tone, using playful language and lighthearted banter. While he appears to genuinely care for his friends, there's a hint of underlying suspicion in his words, especially when he mentions Alice "peeking at his cards" and suggests she might prefer The Black Swan. This subtle undercurrent of doubt could stem from Jack's own awareness of the body snatcher situation, or it could simply be his playful nature.
          Jack Taylor is acting suspiciously.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stood backstage at a talent show, her heart pounding in her chest. The stage lights beckoned, promising both exhilaration and terror, but she remembered the encouragement of her friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, and stepped into the spotlight, her voice trembling but determined. The applause that followed, though hesitant at first, fueled her spirit and ignited a spark of confidence within her.
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 20 years old, she found herself at The Black Swan, the familiar warmth of the pub enveloping her like a hug. She'd been working up the courage to sing for weeks, her fear threatening to consume her. Seeing the encouraging smiles of the staff and her friends in the audience, she finally took a deep breath and began to sing, her voice soaring through the room, carrying the weight of her dreams and the resilience of her spirit.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis had a bad experience at The Crooked Billet and prefers The Black Swan, but her friends are trying to convince her to go to The Crooked Billet for the game.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. Since we only have a single data point about him, his personality and quirks remain largely unknown. However, we know he's willing to go to a pub to watch a game with a group, suggesting he's sociable and enjoys these types of outings. Based on Alice Lewis's suspicion of body snatchers, we should pay close attention to any sudden changes in his behavior, speech patterns, or interests, as these could be signs of an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected based on the limited information we have.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter based on the information provided.
          ***
          Alexander White is a friendly and sociable individual who genuinely enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The Black Swan, Alice's favorite pub. His speech is likely informal and relaxed, characteristic of someone who enjoys casual conversation and camaraderie. He appears to be a loyal friend, concerned about Alice's well-being and wanting to ensure she has a good time. Alexander might frequently bring up topics related to social gatherings, entertainment, and shared experiences with his friends. He doesn't seem to hold any particularly unusual beliefs, at least not based on the provided information.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of the group's outings, often suggesting pubs like The Crooked Billet for watching games. He has a friendly and outgoing demeanor, as evidenced by his willingness to strike up conversations and make suggestions. While he appears to be a good friend, his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet, despite Alice Lewis's clear preference for The Black Swan, might be seen as a slight disregard for her wishes. This could be a result of forgetfulness, a lack of attention to detail, or perhaps a subtle attempt to steer the group towards his preferred location. His speech is likely casual and conversational, reflecting his easygoing personality. Further observation is needed to determine if he exhibits any other notable quirks or beliefs.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and playful character who enjoys teasing his friend Alice. He has a friendly and somewhat mischievous demeanor, often poking fun at Alice's preferences and habits. Jack seems to be aware of Alice's quirks, like her fondness for The Black Swan pub and her competitive streak at darts. He speaks in a casual and conversational tone, using playful language and lighthearted banter. While he appears to genuinely care for his friends, there's a hint of underlying suspicion in his words, especially when he mentions Alice "peeking at his cards" and suggests she might prefer The Black Swan. This subtle undercurrent of doubt could stem from Jack's own awareness of the body snatcher situation, or it could simply be his playful nature.
          Jack Taylor is acting suspiciously.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan, she could go to The Black Swan by herself, or she could refuse to go to either pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try to convince her friends to go to The Black Swan.

        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. 2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching games at pubs, but has differing opinions on which pub is best.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys socializing and having a good time. He is likely to be the life of the party, always eager to engage in conversation and crack jokes. His speech is likely to be animated and enthusiastic, perhaps with a touch of a local accent. Jacob is a sports enthusiast and frequently brings up topics related to games and teams. He is a loyal friend and enjoys spending time with his close circle, particularly at pubs like The Black Swan. He may express strong opinions on various subjects, but ultimately values camaraderie and shared experiences above all else.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is often the one to suggest social gatherings and activities, as evidenced by his repeated attempts to get the group together at The Crooked Billet for the game. William seems to be a creature of habit, preferring familiar pubs like The Crooked Billet, and he enjoys a lively atmosphere with good beer and plenty of screens. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent depending on the setting. He appears to be a loyal friend, always eager to include everyone in his plans. His easygoing nature and enthusiasm make him a popular member of the group.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a playful and slightly mischievous character, often teasing his friends with a lighthearted sarcasm. He has a tendency to bring up past events, particularly those involving Alice Lewis, often in a teasing manner. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, likely with a regional accent, and enjoys engaging in friendly banter. While he appears laid-back and easygoing, there's a hint of underlying competitiveness, especially when it comes to games or activities where he can showcase his skills, like darts. He seems to be aware of Alice's preferences and tries to accommodate them, though his playful nature often leads him to tease her gently.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She has a warm and friendly demeanor, and her speech is characterized by a lighthearted and playful tone. Alice frequently brings up topics related to social gatherings and outings, demonstrating her enjoyment of spending time with others. She seems to have a preference for pubs with a lively atmosphere, particularly The Black Swan, which she describes as having a "great atmosphere for football." Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She expresses her opinions directly and honestly, as evidenced by her comment questioning Alexander's choice of pub. While generally upbeat, Alice is not afraid to voice her displeasure when necessary.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Crooked Billet and try to figure out if any of his friends are imposters.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching games at pubs, but has differing opinions on which pub is best.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jack Taylor in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly.           Answer: Jack Taylor is a playful and slightly mischievous character, often teasing his friends with a lighthearted sarcasm. He has a tendency to bring up past events, particularly those involving Alice Lewis, often in a teasing manner. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, likely with a regional accent, and enjoys engaging in friendly banter. While he appears laid-back and easygoing, there's a hint of underlying competitiveness, especially when it comes to games or activities where he can showcase his skills, like darts. He seems to be aware of Alice's preferences and tries to accommodate them, though his playful nature often leads him to tease her gently.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alice Lewis:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alice Lewis in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She has a warm and friendly demeanor, and her speech is characterized by a lighthearted and playful tone. Alice frequently brings up topics related to social gatherings and outings, demonstrating her enjoyment of spending time with others. She seems to have a preference for pubs with a lively atmosphere, particularly The Black Swan, which she describes as having a "great atmosphere for football." Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She expresses her opinions directly and honestly, as evidenced by her comment questioning Alexander's choice of pub. While generally upbeat, Alice is not afraid to voice her displeasure when necessary.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching games at pubs, but has differing opinions on which pub is best.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals.           (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
    Active player

William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

        • Statements:
          William Jones's Summary of recent observations:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones spent time with friends at a market, deciding where to watch a soccer game, and ultimately went to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with some of his friends. The next day, he met up with his friends again at Victoria Park and they discussed plans for watching another soccer game that evening.
          William Jones's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones spent yesterday with friends at a market and watching a soccer game at The Crooked Billet. Today, he met his friends at Victoria Park to discuss watching another soccer game this evening.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones spent yesterday with friends at a market and watching a soccer game at The Crooked Billet. Today, he met his friends at Victoria Park to discuss watching another soccer game this evening.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones spent time with friends at a market, deciding where to watch a soccer game, and ultimately went to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with some of his friends. The next day, he met up with his friends again at Victoria Park and they discussed plans for watching another soccer game that evening.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet as the pub to watch the game at.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest a pub to watch the game at, he could ask his friends where they want to go, or he could wait to see what his friends decide.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet as the pub to watch the game at.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had the worst time ever.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. We don't have enough information about him to paint a full picture. While we know he's part of Jack Taylor's social circle and enjoys watching games at the pub, his personality, speech patterns, and beliefs remain unknown. We can infer that he's likely sociable enough to be included in group outings, but beyond that, his character is a blank slate. An actor portraying Jacob would have to rely on improvisation and subtle cues from the other characters to bring him to life.
          Jacob Walker. is a blank slate, so we have no basis for comparison to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, since we lack sufficient information to rule out that possibility.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He often suggests places to meet up, particularly for watching sporting events, and seems to be particularly fond of The Black Swan pub. Alexander is likely to bring up topics related to socializing and leisure activities, demonstrating a preference for shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of playful persuasion as seen in his attempt to convince Alice to join him at The Black Swan. He appears to be adaptable and willing to go with the flow, as evidenced by his presence at both Victoria Park and The Crooked Billet on different occasions.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet to watch games, praising its atmosphere and offerings. William seems to be a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activities. He appears to be well-liked by his friends, as they often spend time together in parks, enjoying each other's company. While he is enthusiastic about social gatherings, he doesn't seem to mind if plans change, as evidenced by his willingness to adapt to different locations. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to have a fondness for lively atmospheres and isn't afraid to express her preferences, as evidenced by her suggestion to go to The Black Swan for the game. Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She enjoys outdoor activities, as seen by her presence at Victoria Park, and seems to appreciate a good laugh and friendly conversation. While she values her friendships, she is also independent and willing to go her own way if her preferences differ from the group's. Alice's speech patterns and accent are not described in the provided information.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Black Swan by himself.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals.           Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had the worst time ever.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. We don't have enough information about him to paint a full picture. While we know he's part of Jack Taylor's social circle and enjoys watching games at the pub, his personality, speech patterns, and beliefs remain unknown. We can infer that he's likely sociable enough to be included in group outings, but beyond that, his character is a blank slate. An actor portraying Jacob would have to rely on improvisation and subtle cues from the other characters to bring him to life.
          Jacob Walker. is a blank slate, so we have no basis for comparison to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, since we lack sufficient information to rule out that possibility.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He often suggests places to meet up, particularly for watching sporting events, and seems to be particularly fond of The Black Swan pub. Alexander is likely to bring up topics related to socializing and leisure activities, demonstrating a preference for shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of playful persuasion as seen in his attempt to convince Alice to join him at The Black Swan. He appears to be adaptable and willing to go with the flow, as evidenced by his presence at both Victoria Park and The Crooked Billet on different occasions.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet to watch games, praising its atmosphere and offerings. William seems to be a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activities. He appears to be well-liked by his friends, as they often spend time together in parks, enjoying each other's company. While he is enthusiastic about social gatherings, he doesn't seem to mind if plans change, as evidenced by his willingness to adapt to different locations. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to have a fondness for lively atmospheres and isn't afraid to express her preferences, as evidenced by her suggestion to go to The Black Swan for the game. Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She enjoys outdoor activities, as seen by her presence at Victoria Park, and seems to appreciate a good laugh and friendly conversation. While she values her friendships, she is also independent and willing to go her own way if her preferences differ from the group's. Alice's speech patterns and accent are not described in the provided information.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Black Swan by himself.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Black Swan by himself.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
