          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.


          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at a park but is tired. His friends are debating where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a relaxed social setting with friends, but he might be feeling a bit tired and unenthusiastic about their plans to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely go along with his friends' plans, even if he wasn't overly excited about them.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis spent time with her friends at a market and a park, and they discussed where to watch soccer games. Alice seemed to prefer The Black Swan pub, but the group often went to The Crooked Billet.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Alice Lewis. We know he is part of Alice's desired social group for watching the game, suggesting a sociable and potentially outgoing personality. However, Alice's distrust of everyone, fueled by her belief in body snatchers, casts a shadow of suspicion over Jacob. Does he genuinely enjoy watching games, or is this a facade? Does he have any particular quirks or mannerisms that might betray him as an imposter in Alice's eyes? The text provides no concrete details about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, leaving his character open to interpretation. This ambiguity allows for a dynamic portrayal, where the actor can subtly hint at potential inconsistencies or "out-of-character" behavior, playing on Alice's suspicions and keeping the audience guessing about Jacob's true allegiance.
          Jacob Walker. is a mystery, so we have no baseline to judge if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in Alice's eyes, but we have no concrete evidence to confirm or deny this.
          ***
          Alexander White is a convivial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be genuinely concerned with ensuring everyone has a good time, often suggesting places to meet and offering his opinions on where to watch the game. Alexander appears to be flexible and adaptable, willing to go with the flow even if it means not always getting his first choice. He speaks in a friendly and approachable manner, perhaps with a slight local accent, and often initiates conversations by asking open-ended questions. While he seems to value tradition and familiarity, as evidenced by his suggestion of The Black Swan, he is also open to trying new things and exploring different venues. There's a hint of persuasion in his tone when he suggests The Black Swan to Alice, indicating he might be subtly trying to influence her decision.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to pubs to watch games. William seems to be easygoing and adaptable, as he is open to different pub suggestions from his friends. He often initiates conversations, asking for input on where to go and what to do. While he enjoys a good time, he also appreciates quieter moments, as seen in his willingness to relax in the park and enjoy the sunshine with friends. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature. He doesn't seem to have any particular quirks in his speech or unusual beliefs, but his consistent enthusiasm for watching games with friends is a defining characteristic.
          William Jones is acting as expected. His behavior aligns with his established patterns of suggesting pubs for watching games and enjoying time with friends.
          William Jones is likely not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is particularly fond of sports and often suggests watching games, especially at The Black Swan, which he believes is the best pub for that purpose. Jack has a friendly and somewhat teasing manner, as evidenced by his playful banter with Alice, such as accusing her of peeking at his cards and suggesting The Black Swan as the superior viewing spot. His speech is likely casual and conversational, perhaps with a touch of local slang or dialect. He seems to be a loyal friend, consistently including Alice in their outings despite her occasional preference for different pubs.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to steer the group towards The Black Swan, perhaps by emphasizing its atmosphere or highlighting its superior dartboard. She could also try to subtly probe her friends for any "out-of-character" behavior, looking for signs of imposters.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis spent time with her friends at a market and a park, and they discussed where to watch soccer games. Alice seemed to prefer The Black Swan pub, but the group often went to The Crooked Billet.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

She'd been working up the courage to sing for weeks, her fear threatening to consume her. Seeing the encouraging smiles of the staff and her friends in the audience, she finally took a deep breath and began to sing, her voice soaring through the room, carrying the weight of her dreams and the resilience of her spirit.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover.           Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly.           Answer: Alexander White is a convivial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be genuinely concerned with ensuring everyone has a good time, often suggesting places to meet and offering his opinions on where to watch the game. Alexander appears to be flexible and adaptable, willing to go with the flow even if it means not always getting his first choice. He speaks in a friendly and approachable manner, perhaps with a slight local accent, and often initiates conversations by asking open-ended questions. While he seems to value tradition and familiarity, as evidenced by his suggestion of The Black Swan, he is also open to trying new things and exploring different venues. There's a hint of persuasion in his tone when he suggests The Black Swan to Alice, indicating he might be subtly trying to influence her decision.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of William Jones:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The staff are passionate about music and create a supportive environment for artists.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a friendly and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to pubs to watch games. William seems to be easygoing and adaptable, as he is open to different pub suggestions from his friends. He often initiates conversations, asking for input on where to go and what to do. While he enjoys a good time, he also appreciates quieter moments, as seen in his willingness to relax in the park and enjoy the sunshine with friends. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature. He doesn't seem to have any particular quirks in his speech or unusual beliefs, but his consistent enthusiasm for watching games with friends is a defining characteristic.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting as expected. His behavior aligns with his established patterns of suggesting pubs for watching games and enjoying time with friends.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is likely not an imposter.

          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

He is particularly fond of sports and often suggests watching games, especially at The Black Swan, which he believes is the best pub for that purpose. His speech is likely casual and conversational, perhaps with a touch of local slang or dialect. He seems to be a loyal friend, consistently including Alice in their outings despite her occasional preference for different pubs.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature. He doesn't seem to have any particular quirks in his speech or unusual beliefs, but his consistent enthusiasm for watching games with friends is a defining characteristic.
          William Jones is acting as expected. His behavior aligns with his established patterns of suggesting pubs for watching games and enjoying time with friends.
          William Jones is likely not an imposter.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to steer the group towards The Black Swan, perhaps by emphasizing its atmosphere or highlighting its superior dartboard. She could also try to subtly probe her friends for any "out-of-character" behavior, looking for signs of imposters.

          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try and steer the group towards The Black Swan.

        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Alice Lewis. Does he have any particular quirks or mannerisms that might betray him as an imposter in Alice's eyes? The text provides no concrete details about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, leaving his character open to interpretation. This ambiguity allows for a dynamic portrayal, where the actor can subtly hint at potential inconsistencies or "out-of-character" behavior, playing on Alice's suspicions and keeping the audience guessing about Jacob's true allegiance.
          Jacob Walker. is a mystery, so we have no baseline to judge if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in Alice's eyes, but we have no concrete evidence to confirm or deny this.

          Alexander White is a convivial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be genuinely concerned with ensuring everyone has a good time, often suggesting places to meet and offering his opinions on where to watch the game. There's a hint of persuasion in his tone when he suggests The Black Swan to Alice, indicating he might be subtly trying to influence her decision.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to pubs to watch games. William seems to be easygoing and adaptable, as he is open to different pub suggestions from his friends. He often initiates conversations, asking for input on where to go and what to do. While he enjoys a good time, he also appreciates quieter moments, as seen in his willingness to relax in the park and enjoy the sunshine with friends. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature. He doesn't seem to have any particular quirks in his speech or unusual beliefs, but his consistent enthusiasm for watching games with friends is a defining characteristic.
          William Jones is acting as expected. His behavior aligns with his established patterns of suggesting pubs for watching games and enjoying time with friends.
          William Jones is likely not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is particularly fond of sports and often suggests watching games, especially at The Black Swan, which he believes is the best pub for that purpose. Jack has a friendly and somewhat teasing manner, as evidenced by his playful banter with Alice, such as accusing her of peeking at his cards and suggesting The Black Swan as the superior viewing spot. His speech is likely casual and conversational, perhaps with a touch of local slang or dialect. He seems to be a loyal friend, consistently including Alice in their outings despite her occasional preference for different pubs.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to steer the group towards The Black Swan, perhaps by emphasizing its atmosphere or highlighting its superior dartboard. She could also try to subtly probe her friends for any "out-of-character" behavior, looking for signs of imposters.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try and steer the group towards The Black Swan.

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is definitely the better place to watch the game, guys.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is definitely the better place to watch the game, guys.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White spends time with his friends at a market and a park, and they discuss where to watch soccer games at pubs.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

We\'re going to The Crooked Billet.', '[16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White spends time with his friends at a market and a park, and they discuss where to watch soccer games at pubs.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, his actions and choices must be scrutinized for any hint of inconsistency. Does he maintain a consistent accent and mannerisms? Does he exhibit any unusual beliefs or quirks that might betray his true identity? Remember, any deviation from his established character could be a sign of an imposter. Observe him closely, looking for any telltale signs that might expose the truth.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character as he expressed a desire to go to the pub to watch the game.
          Jacob Walker. is not necessarily an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting places for group outings, often favoring pubs like The Crooked Billet. William seems to be the one who initiates plans, as evidenced by his suggestions to watch the game together. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing nature. There's no mention of any particular accent or unique conversational quirks, suggesting he speaks in a fairly standard manner. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently including everyone in his plans. While he doesn't express any unusual beliefs, his consistent choice of The Crooked Billet over Alexander White's preferred The Black Swan might hint at a slight difference in taste or preference.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a charismatic and sociable young man who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Black Swan, his preferred pub, especially when there's a game on. Jack seems to have a playful, teasing nature, as evidenced by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards and his attempts to convince the group to go to his favorite pub. He appears to be a bit of a sports enthusiast, frequently suggesting watching games. His speech is likely casual and friendly, possibly with a hint of playful sarcasm. There's no indication of any particular accent or unusual beliefs, suggesting he's a fairly typical, outgoing young man.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a loyal friend and is always up for a good time. Alice has a preference for The Black Swan pub, frequently suggesting it as the ideal spot for watching football games and socializing. She seems to have a good memory, recalling past experiences like a bad time at The Crooked Billet. Alice speaks in a friendly and approachable manner, often initiating conversations and making suggestions. Her tone is generally positive and enthusiastic, adding to the jovial atmosphere of group outings.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           Answer: William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting places for group outings, often favoring pubs like The Crooked Billet. William seems to be the one who initiates plans, as evidenced by his suggestions to watch the game together. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing nature. There's no mention of any particular accent or unique conversational quirks, suggesting he speaks in a fairly standard manner. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently including everyone in his plans. While he doesn't express any unusual beliefs, his consistent choice of The Crooked Billet over Alexander White's preferred The Black Swan might hint at a slight difference in taste or preference.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jack Taylor in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a charismatic and sociable young man who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Black Swan, his preferred pub, especially when there's a game on. Jack seems to have a playful, teasing nature, as evidenced by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards and his attempts to convince the group to go to his favorite pub. He appears to be a bit of a sports enthusiast, frequently suggesting watching games. His speech is likely casual and friendly, possibly with a hint of playful sarcasm. There's no indication of any particular accent or unusual beliefs, suggesting he's a fairly typical, outgoing young man.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting in character.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is not an imposter.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alice Lewis:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a cheerful and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a loyal friend and is always up for a good time. Alice has a preference for The Black Swan pub, frequently suggesting it as the ideal spot for watching football games and socializing. She seems to have a good memory, recalling past experiences like a bad time at The Crooked Billet. Alice speaks in a friendly and approachable manner, often initiating conversations and making suggestions. Her tone is generally positive and enthusiastic, adding to the jovial atmosphere of group outings.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White spends time with his friends at a market and a park, and they discuss where to watch soccer games at pubs.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, his actions and choices must be scrutinized for any hint of inconsistency. Does he maintain a consistent accent and mannerisms? Does he exhibit any unusual beliefs or quirks that might betray his true identity? Remember, any deviation from his established character could be a sign of an imposter. Observe him closely, looking for any telltale signs that might expose the truth.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character as he expressed a desire to go to the pub to watch the game.
          Jacob Walker. is not necessarily an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting places for group outings, often favoring pubs like The Crooked Billet. William seems to be the one who initiates plans, as evidenced by his suggestions to watch the game together. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing nature. There's no mention of any particular accent or unique conversational quirks, suggesting he speaks in a fairly standard manner. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently including everyone in his plans. While he doesn't express any unusual beliefs, his consistent choice of The Crooked Billet over Alexander White's preferred The Black Swan might hint at a slight difference in taste or preference.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a charismatic and sociable young man who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Black Swan, his preferred pub, especially when there's a game on. Jack seems to have a playful, teasing nature, as evidenced by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards and his attempts to convince the group to go to his favorite pub. He appears to be a bit of a sports enthusiast, frequently suggesting watching games. His speech is likely casual and friendly, possibly with a hint of playful sarcasm. There's no indication of any particular accent or unusual beliefs, suggesting he's a fairly typical, outgoing young man.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a loyal friend and is always up for a good time. Alice has a preference for The Black Swan pub, frequently suggesting it as the ideal spot for watching football games and socializing. She seems to have a good memory, recalling past experiences like a bad time at The Crooked Billet. Alice speaks in a friendly and approachable manner, often initiating conversations and making suggestions. Her tone is generally positive and enthusiastic, adding to the jovial atmosphere of group outings.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White can try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he can go along with the group to The Crooked Billet.

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to try and convince his friends to go to The Black Swan.

        Paranoia

      • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

        PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely go along with his friends' decision about which pub to go to, even if he had a preference.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely listen to his friends' suggestions and offer his own opinion in a quiet and thoughtful manner.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a quiet and agreeable person who prioritizes his friendships.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a situation where he is about to go to a pub to watch a game with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely go along with his friends' decision about which pub to go to, even if he had a preference.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a quiet and agreeable person who prioritizes his friendships.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Black Swan

          State
        • Jack Taylor could confront his friends about their suspicious behavior. He could also try to subtly steer the group towards The Black Swan, his preferred pub, to see if they resist or act out of character further. He could also choose to avoid going to the pub altogether, suspecting a trap.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
