        PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely be quietly observing his friends, enjoying their company and the pleasant atmosphere.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Alice, effortlessly aced their tryouts for the school's basketball team. He'd practiced too, but his shots always seemed to fall short, his passes intercepted. He sat alone in The Crooked Billet that night, the pub unusually quiet, the aroma of ale doing little to lift his spirits. He envied their camaraderie, their effortless skill, and the way they seemed to move through life with such confidence.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in the back of The Crooked Billet, nursing a pint and listening to Alice recount her summer backpacking trip through Europe. Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective individual who yearns for adventure and connection.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon with friends before heading to a pub to watch a football game.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be quietly observing his friends, enjoying their company and the pleasant atmosphere.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he scored the winning goal in the local youth league finals, sending his team into raptures. The roar of the crowd, the feeling of the ball hitting the back of the net, the cheers of his teammates – it was a moment of pure exhilaration that cemented his love for the game. He knew in that moment that football was his destiny.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending time with friends, watching the European football cup, and deciding where to watch the Andorra vs Portugal game.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. While we have limited information about him directly, his inclusion in Jack Taylor's desired pub gathering suggests he is part of their social circle. We can infer that he enjoys watching games and socializing, as Jack Taylor hopes they will all have a good time together. However, given Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers, Jacob's behavior should be closely observed for any inconsistencies. Any sudden changes in his demeanor, speech patterns, or interests could be a sign that he is not who he appears to be. Remember, in Jack Taylor's world, even the most mundane details could hold the key to unmasking an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He is likely to have a warm and friendly demeanor, perhaps with a touch of playful teasing. His speech is likely to be casual and easygoing, reflecting his relaxed and approachable personality. He is interested in shared experiences, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game together. He may have a penchant for suggesting activities that involve socializing and having fun, such as going to pubs or enjoying outdoor gatherings. While his specific accent and conversational quirks are not explicitly mentioned, his enthusiasm for spending time with friends and engaging in lighthearted conversation suggests a personality that is outgoing and enjoys the company of others.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a creature of habit, suggesting The Crooked Billet as a familiar and favored spot to watch the game. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He enjoys simple pleasures like picnics in the park and good company. While his beliefs about body snatchers are not explicitly stated, his willingness to spend time in public with his friends suggests he may not share Jack Taylor's paranoia. He appears to be a reliable and trustworthy friend, someone who values tradition and enjoys the simple things in life.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a penchant for suggesting popular pubs, as evidenced by her recommendation of The Black Swan. She seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as indicated by her enjoyment of the children's laughter in the park. Alice is likely outgoing and friendly, comfortable in social settings and eager to engage in conversation. Her speech is likely informal and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. We don't have enough information to determine her accent or any particular conversational quirks, but based on her suggestion of The Black Swan, she may have a preference for traditional pubs with a classic feel.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.

          Answer: Jack Taylor could publicly accuse Alice Lewis of something like cheating at a game or making a rude comment to create a conflict with a plausible excuse.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of William Jones:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a creature of habit, suggesting The Crooked Billet as a familiar and favored spot to watch the game. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He enjoys simple pleasures like picnics in the park and good company. While his beliefs about body snatchers are not explicitly stated, his willingness to spend time in public with his friends suggests he may not share Jack Taylor's paranoia. He appears to be a reliable and trustworthy friend, someone who values tradition and enjoys the simple things in life.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a jovial and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a penchant for suggesting popular pubs, as evidenced by her recommendation of The Black Swan. She seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as indicated by her enjoyment of the children's laughter in the park. Alice is likely outgoing and friendly, comfortable in social settings and eager to engage in conversation. Her speech is likely informal and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. We don't have enough information to determine her accent or any particular conversational quirks, but based on her suggestion of The Black Swan, she may have a preference for traditional pubs with a classic feel.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending time with friends, watching the European football cup, and deciding where to watch the Andorra vs Portugal game.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. 2015-05-15 10:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. 2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: William Jones spent the previous day with friends at a park and a pub watching football, wishing more people had joined them. Currently, it is May 15, 2015, and he is reflecting on the previous day.

        • William Jones, William Jones spent the previous day with friends at a park and a pub watching football, wishing more people had joined them. Currently, it is May 15, 2015, and he is reflecting on the previous day.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones spent time with friends at a park and later at a pub watching football games. He enjoyed the company of his friends but wished more people had joined them for the games.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?

          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White spent time with friends at the park and a pub, watching football games and enjoying each other's company. He seemed to have a pleasant time despite some minor preferences not being met.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is Jacob Walker is a character shrouded in uncertainty due to Alexander White's paranoia. While we know he enjoys watching games at pubs, particularly The Black Swan, and is part of a social group that includes Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, William Jones, and Alexander White himself, his personality and speech patterns remain largely unknown. Alexander White's focus on spotting imposters based on behavioral inconsistencies leaves us with no concrete details about Jacob's normal demeanor, accent, or conversational style. He could be jovial and outgoing, quiet and reserved, or anything in between. Until further information is revealed, Jacob Walker remains a blank slate, a potential imposter in Alexander White's eyes.
          Jacob Walker. is a cipher, so we can't determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a suspect in Alexander White's eyes, but we lack sufficient information to determine if he is truly an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He is often the one to suggest social outings, particularly favoring pubs like The Crooked Billet for watching games. He seems to be a creature of habit, frequently suggesting familiar places and activities. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often initiates conversations by suggesting plans or activities. While he appears to be a loyal and supportive friend, there's a hint of a potential ulterior motive behind his suggestions, as he consistently steers the group towards The Crooked Billet, even when others express a preference for The Black Swan. This could be due to a genuine preference for the pub or something more subtle, perhaps a desire to maintain a certain dynamic within the group.
          William Jones is acting in a way that is consistent with his established character.
          William Jones is likely not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and carefree individual who enjoys playful banter and lighthearted teasing. He likely speaks with a casual, friendly tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Jack seems to enjoy games and friendly competition, as evidenced by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards. He is comfortable in social settings and seems to enjoy spending time with his friends, participating in activities like picnics in the park and outings to pubs. While his exact beliefs are not explicitly stated, his playful nature suggests he might hold a lighthearted outlook on life and doesn't take himself too seriously. He seems to be comfortable in a variety of social settings, from bustling markets to cozy pubs.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a homebody, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan pub. Alice is likely to be cheerful and upbeat, perhaps with a touch of nostalgia for simpler times, evidenced by her fondness for checkered blankets and picnics in the park. She enjoys lively conversation and is likely to bring up topics like local events, shared memories, or upcoming social gatherings. While she may not be particularly vocal about her opinions, her actions suggest a preference for tradition and familiarity. Alice's speech is likely to be casual and friendly, perhaps with a hint of a local accent.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could confront Alice Lewis about her out-of-character behavior, accusing her of something mundane and plausible to mask his true suspicions. He could also try to subtly steer the group towards The Black Swan, hoping to observe Alice's reactions and gather more information.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White spent time with friends at the park and a pub, watching football games and enjoying each other's company. He seemed to have a pleasant time despite some minor preferences not being met.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is Jacob Walker is a character shrouded in uncertainty due to Alexander White's paranoia. While we know he enjoys watching games at pubs, particularly The Black Swan, and is part of a social group that includes Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, William Jones, and Alexander White himself, his personality and speech patterns remain largely unknown. Alexander White's focus on spotting imposters based on behavioral inconsistencies leaves us with no concrete details about Jacob's normal demeanor, accent, or conversational style. He could be jovial and outgoing, quiet and reserved, or anything in between. Until further information is revealed, Jacob Walker remains a blank slate, a potential imposter in Alexander White's eyes.
          Jacob Walker. is a cipher, so we can't determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a suspect in Alexander White's eyes, but we lack sufficient information to determine if he is truly an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He is often the one to suggest social outings, particularly favoring pubs like The Crooked Billet for watching games. He seems to be a creature of habit, frequently suggesting familiar places and activities. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often initiates conversations by suggesting plans or activities. While he appears to be a loyal and supportive friend, there's a hint of a potential ulterior motive behind his suggestions, as he consistently steers the group towards The Crooked Billet, even when others express a preference for The Black Swan. This could be due to a genuine preference for the pub or something more subtle, perhaps a desire to maintain a certain dynamic within the group.
          William Jones is acting in a way that is consistent with his established character.
          William Jones is likely not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and carefree individual who enjoys playful banter and lighthearted teasing. He likely speaks with a casual, friendly tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Jack seems to enjoy games and friendly competition, as evidenced by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards. He is comfortable in social settings and seems to enjoy spending time with his friends, participating in activities like picnics in the park and outings to pubs. While his exact beliefs are not explicitly stated, his playful nature suggests he might hold a lighthearted outlook on life and doesn't take himself too seriously. He seems to be comfortable in a variety of social settings, from bustling markets to cozy pubs.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing young woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a homebody, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan pub. Alice is likely to be cheerful and upbeat, perhaps with a touch of nostalgia for simpler times, evidenced by her fondness for checkered blankets and picnics in the park. She enjoys lively conversation and is likely to bring up topics like local events, shared memories, or upcoming social gatherings. While she may not be particularly vocal about her opinions, her actions suggest a preference for tradition and familiarity. Alice's speech is likely to be casual and friendly, perhaps with a hint of a local accent.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could confront Alice Lewis about her out-of-character behavior, accusing her of something mundane and plausible to mask his true suspicions. He could also try to subtly steer the group towards The Black Swan, hoping to observe Alice's reactions and gather more information.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00

      • Alexander White's TRUTH

          Value

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"

          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis could confront Alexander White about his suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet, accusing him of acting out of character and potentially being an imposter. She could also choose to ignore Alexander's suggestion and insist on going to The Black Swan, hoping her friends will follow her lead. Alternatively, she could try to subtly probe Alexander for inconsistencies in his behavior or speech, looking for any signs that might confirm her suspicions.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys spending time with her friends, often meeting them at parks or pubs to socialize and watch football games. However, she sometimes feels left out or disappointed when her plans don't align with the group's decisions.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of Alice Lewis' social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at pubs. His preferences align with the group, suggesting a sociable and perhaps easygoing personality. However, given Alice Lewis' paranoia about body snatchers, it's crucial to observe Jacob closely for any inconsistencies in his behavior or speech. Does he maintain a consistent accent and mannerisms? Does he express any unusual beliefs or exhibit any quirks that could betray him as an imposter? Until further information is revealed, Jacob remains an enigma, his true nature a subject of suspicion and speculation.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected based on the limited information we have.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be considerate of Alice's preferences, as evidenced by his suggestion to go to The Black Swan. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He frequently brings up social activities, particularly watching games, and seems to be a regular at pubs like The Crooked Billet and The Black Swan. He may have a strong sense of camaraderie and loyalty towards his friends, as he expresses concern when Alice chooses to go to a different pub.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a fan of sports, particularly suggesting The Crooked Billet as a place to watch games. He's also fond of lively atmospheres, as evidenced by his choice of pubs and his enjoyment of outdoor gatherings in parks and markets. William appears to be easygoing and agreeable, readily making suggestions for group activities. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his approachable nature. He doesn't seem to share Alice's suspicions about body snatchers, as he continues to suggest The Crooked Billet despite Alice's previous negative experience there.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and playful character, quick with a teasing remark and a mischievous grin. He likely speaks with a casual, friendly tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys lighthearted banter and doesn't shy away from playful accusations, as seen when he playfully accuses Alice of peeking at his cards. He seems to enjoy spending time with friends, participating in group activities like picnics and outings to the market. While he might not be deeply philosophical, Jack likely enjoys light conversation and sharing stories, contributing to the overall jovial atmosphere of his social gatherings.
          Jack Taylor is acting in character. His playful accusation towards Alice about peeking at his cards aligns with his previously observed behavior of lighthearted teasing and banter.
          Jack Taylor is unlikely to be an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could confront Alexander White about his suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet, accusing him of acting out of character and potentially being an imposter. She could also choose to ignore Alexander's suggestion and insist on going to The Black Swan, hoping her friends will follow her lead. Alternatively, she could try to subtly probe Alexander for inconsistencies in his behavior or speech, looking for any signs that might confirm her suspicions.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

She'd been working up the courage to sing for weeks, her fear threatening to consume her. Seeing the encouraging smiles of the staff and her friends in the audience, she finally took a deep breath and began to sing, her voice soaring through the room, carrying the weight of her dreams and the resilience of her spirit.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a fan of sports, particularly suggesting The Crooked Billet as a place to watch games. He's also fond of lively atmospheres, as evidenced by his choice of pubs and his enjoyment of outdoor gatherings in parks and markets. William appears to be easygoing and agreeable, readily making suggestions for group activities. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his approachable nature. He doesn't seem to share Alice's suspicions about body snatchers, as he continues to suggest The Crooked Billet despite Alice's previous negative experience there.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The staff are passionate about music and create a supportive environment for artists.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and playful character, quick with a teasing remark and a mischievous grin. He likely speaks with a casual, friendly tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys lighthearted banter and doesn't shy away from playful accusations, as seen when he playfully accuses Alice of peeking at his cards. He seems to enjoy spending time with friends, participating in group activities like picnics and outings to the market. While he might not be deeply philosophical, Jack likely enjoys light conversation and sharing stories, contributing to the overall jovial atmosphere of his social gatherings.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting in character. His playful accusation towards Alice about peeking at his cards aligns with his previously observed behavior of lighthearted teasing and banter.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is unlikely to be an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys spending time with her friends, often meeting them at parks or pubs to socialize and watch football games. However, she sometimes feels left out or disappointed when her plans don't align with the group's decisions.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Value
