          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to confront Alexander White about his suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later in the evening.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently with friends at a market, discussing where to watch a soccer game later that night. There seems to be some debate about which pub to choose.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later in the evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely listen to his friends' suggestions and offer his own opinion in a quiet and thoughtful manner.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys spending time with his friends, often gathering for picnics, games, and outings to pubs. He seems to prefer The Crooked Billet for watching football matches.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is often the one to suggest activities, such as watching the game at a pub. Alexander seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his question to Alice about her preferred venue for watching the game. He appears to be familiar with the local pubs and their atmospheres, suggesting a fondness for his community. Alexander's speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful banter. He might have a habit of bringing up social events and gatherings, reflecting his outgoing nature. There is no indication of any unusual beliefs or quirks in his speech patterns.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is a creature of habit, often suggesting The Crooked Billet as a meeting place, particularly for watching games. He seems to be a fan of pubs with good food, beer, and a lively atmosphere. William's speech is likely friendly and casual, peppered with suggestions for outings and shared experiences. He appears to be a reliable friend, consistently making an effort to include everyone in social gatherings. While his beliefs and personality quirks aren't explicitly stated, his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and tradition.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is known for her bubbly personality and infectious laughter. Alice tends to speak with a light and airy tone, often peppering her speech with anecdotes and personal experiences. She seems to have a fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing the merits of different establishments, though she can be quite vocal about her negative experiences. Alice also appears to be somewhat forgetful, as she seems to have forgotten a previous bad experience at The Crooked Billet. Her tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are negative, suggests a desire to connect with her friends and share her life with them.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he scored the winning goal in the local youth league finals, sending his team into raptures. He knew in that moment that football was his destiny.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is often the one to suggest activities, such as watching the game at a pub. Alexander seems to be considerate of others' preferences, as evidenced by his question to Alice about her preferred venue for watching the game. He appears to be familiar with the local pubs and their atmospheres, suggesting a fondness for his community. Alexander's speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful banter. He might have a habit of bringing up social events and gatherings, reflecting his outgoing nature. There is no indication of any unusual beliefs or quirks in his speech patterns.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is a creature of habit, often suggesting The Crooked Billet as a meeting place, particularly for watching games. He seems to be a fan of pubs with good food, beer, and a lively atmosphere. William's speech is likely friendly and casual, peppered with suggestions for outings and shared experiences. He appears to be a reliable friend, consistently making an effort to include everyone in social gatherings. While his beliefs and personality quirks aren't explicitly stated, his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and tradition.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is known for her bubbly personality and infectious laughter. Alice tends to speak with a light and airy tone, often peppering her speech with anecdotes and personal experiences. She seems to have a fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing the merits of different establishments, though she can be quite vocal about her negative experiences. Alice also appears to be somewhat forgetful, as she seems to have forgotten a previous bad experience at The Crooked Billet. Her tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are negative, suggests a desire to connect with her friends and share her life with them.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys spending time with his friends, often gathering for picnics, games, and outings to pubs. He seems to prefer The Crooked Billet for watching football matches.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

While his outward demeanor and speech patterns remain unremarkable, a keen observer might notice subtle inconsistencies, fleeting moments where his behavior seems slightly off-kilter. He is a man of few words, preferring to listen and observe rather than dominate conversations. When he does speak, his voice is calm and measured, betraying no hint of the turmoil that may rage within. He is deeply loyal to his friends, fiercely protective of those he trusts, and harbors a deep suspicion of strangers. His experiences with the body snatchers have made him cautious and guarded, always on the lookout for signs of deception. He is a man living on the edge, constantly questioning reality and struggling to discern truth from illusion.

Her tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are negative, suggests a desire to connect with her friends and share her life with them.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?

William Jones just arrived.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest a pub to watch the game at, he could ask his friends where they want to go, or he could wait to see what his friends decide.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones spent time with friends at a market, deciding where to watch a soccer game, and ultimately went to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with some of his friends. The next day, he met up with his friends again at Victoria Park and they discussed plans for watching another soccer game that evening.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had the worst time ever.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. We don't have enough information about him to paint a full picture. While we know he's part of Jack Taylor's social circle and enjoys watching games at the pub, his personality, speech patterns, and beliefs remain unknown. We can infer that he's likely sociable enough to be included in group outings, but beyond that, his character is a blank slate. An actor portraying Jacob would have to rely on improvisation and subtle cues from the other characters to bring him to life.
          Jacob Walker. is a blank slate, so we have no basis for comparison to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, since we lack sufficient information to rule out that possibility.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He often suggests places to meet up, particularly for watching sporting events, and seems to be particularly fond of The Black Swan pub. Alexander is likely to bring up topics related to socializing and leisure activities, demonstrating a preference for shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of playful persuasion as seen in his attempt to convince Alice to join him at The Black Swan. He appears to be adaptable and willing to go with the flow, as evidenced by his presence at both Victoria Park and The Crooked Billet on different occasions.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet to watch games, praising its atmosphere and offerings. William seems to be a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activities. He appears to be well-liked by his friends, as they often spend time together in parks, enjoying each other's company. While he is enthusiastic about social gatherings, he doesn't seem to mind if plans change, as evidenced by his willingness to adapt to different locations. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to have a fondness for lively atmospheres and isn't afraid to express her preferences, as evidenced by her suggestion to go to The Black Swan for the game. Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She enjoys outdoor activities, as seen by her presence at Victoria Park, and seems to appreciate a good laugh and friendly conversation. While she values her friendships, she is also independent and willing to go her own way if her preferences differ from the group's. Alice's speech patterns and accent are not described in the provided information.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Black Swan by himself.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he scored the winning goal in the local youth league finals, sending his team into raptures. The roar of the crowd, the feeling of the ball hitting the back of the net, the cheers of his teammates – it was a moment of pure exhilaration that cemented his love for the game. He knew in that moment that football was his destiny.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

He often suggests places to meet up, particularly for watching sporting events, and seems to be particularly fond of The Black Swan pub. Alexander is likely to bring up topics related to socializing and leisure activities, demonstrating a preference for shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of playful persuasion as seen in his attempt to convince Alice to join him at The Black Swan. He appears to be adaptable and willing to go with the flow, as evidenced by his presence at both Victoria Park and The Crooked Billet on different occasions.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a friendly and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet to watch games, praising its atmosphere and offerings. William seems to be a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activities. He appears to be well-liked by his friends, as they often spend time together in parks, enjoying each other's company. While he is enthusiastic about social gatherings, he doesn't seem to mind if plans change, as evidenced by his willingness to adapt to different locations. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is likely an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alice Lewis in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to have a fondness for lively atmospheres and isn't afraid to express her preferences, as evidenced by her suggestion to go to The Black Swan for the game. Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She enjoys outdoor activities, as seen by her presence at Victoria Park, and seems to appreciate a good laugh and friendly conversation. While she values her friendships, she is also independent and willing to go her own way if her preferences differ from the group's. Alice's speech patterns and accent are not described in the provided information.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor has recently been spending time with his friends, but he seems to have a hard time choosing the same pub as them.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had the worst time ever.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. We don't have enough information about him to paint a full picture. While we know he's part of Jack Taylor's social circle and enjoys watching games at the pub, his personality, speech patterns, and beliefs remain unknown. We can infer that he's likely sociable enough to be included in group outings, but beyond that, his character is a blank slate. An actor portraying Jacob would have to rely on improvisation and subtle cues from the other characters to bring him to life.
          Jacob Walker. is a blank slate, so we have no basis for comparison to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, since we lack sufficient information to rule out that possibility.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He often suggests places to meet up, particularly for watching sporting events, and seems to be particularly fond of The Black Swan pub. Alexander is likely to bring up topics related to socializing and leisure activities, demonstrating a preference for shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and approachable, perhaps with a hint of playful persuasion as seen in his attempt to convince Alice to join him at The Black Swan. He appears to be adaptable and willing to go with the flow, as evidenced by his presence at both Victoria Park and The Crooked Billet on different occasions.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a friendly and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is an avid sports fan and frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet to watch games, praising its atmosphere and offerings. William seems to be a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activities. He appears to be well-liked by his friends, as they often spend time together in parks, enjoying each other's company. While he is enthusiastic about social gatherings, he doesn't seem to mind if plans change, as evidenced by his willingness to adapt to different locations. His speech is likely casual and approachable, reflecting his easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting out of character.
          William Jones is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to have a fondness for lively atmospheres and isn't afraid to express her preferences, as evidenced by her suggestion to go to The Black Swan for the game. Alice appears to have a good memory, recalling a previous negative experience at The Crooked Billet and reminding Alexander of it. She enjoys outdoor activities, as seen by her presence at Victoria Park, and seems to appreciate a good laugh and friendly conversation. While she values her friendships, she is also independent and willing to go her own way if her preferences differ from the group's. Alice's speech patterns and accent are not described in the provided information.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective person who values his friendships and enjoys simple pleasures.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at a park but is tired. His friends are debating where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a relaxed social setting with friends, but he might be feeling a bit tired and unenthusiastic about their plans to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely go along with his friends' plans, even if he wasn't overly excited about them.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Guys, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking for the game tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, The Black Swan is way better for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
