2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Alice, effortlessly aced their tryouts for the school's basketball team. He'd practiced too, but his shots always seemed to fall short, his passes intercepted. He sat alone in The Crooked Billet that night, the pub unusually quiet, the aroma of ale doing little to lift his spirits. He envied their camaraderie, their effortless skill, and the way they seemed to move through life with such confidence.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in the back of The Crooked Billet, nursing a pint and listening to Alice recount her summer backpacking trip through Europe. Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.

        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he watched from the sidelines as his friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Alice, effortlessly aced their tryouts for the school's basketball team. He'd practiced too, but his shots always seemed to fall short, his passes intercepted. He sat alone in The Crooked Billet that night, the pub unusually quiet, the aroma of ale doing little to lift his spirits. He envied their camaraderie, their effortless skill, and the way they seemed to move through life with such confidence.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he sat in the back of The Crooked Billet, nursing a pint and listening to Alice recount her summer backpacking trip through Europe. Her stories were filled with vibrant details – cobblestone streets, bustling markets, and encounters with fascinating people. Jacob felt a pang of longing, wishing he had the courage to break free from the predictability of his life and embark on his own adventures. He knew he could never be as bold as Alice, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was meant for something more than the safe, predictable path he was on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a reserved and introspective individual who yearns for adventure and connection.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be quietly observing his friends, enjoying their company and the pleasant atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends in Victoria Park and later plans to watch a football game with them at The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Jack Taylor. We know little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, as Jack's perception is clouded by the suspicion that he might be an imposter. Jack's focus is on identifying behavioral inconsistencies, making it difficult to discern Jacob's genuine traits. However, the fact that Jack wants to watch the game with Jacob suggests a pre-existing relationship, implying a level of familiarity and perhaps even friendship. Until more information is revealed about Jacob's actions and interactions, he remains an enigma, a blank slate upon which Jack's suspicions are projected.
          Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, and we lack sufficient information to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in the eyes of Jack Taylor.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He often initiates conversations, as seen by his question about where to watch the game. Alexander seems to appreciate simple pleasures, like picnicking in the park and sharing stories with friends. While his exact accent and speech patterns aren't specified, his dialogue suggests a casual and friendly tone. He likely values camaraderie and enjoys lighthearted discussions. There's no mention of any unusual beliefs or quirks, suggesting he's a relatively down-to-earth person.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, often suggesting popular gathering spots like The Crooked Billet, known for its lively atmosphere and good food. William appears to be a creature of habit, suggesting familiar locations and activities, and seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends, as evidenced by his participation in their leisurely outings. He is likely to engage in lighthearted conversation, perhaps reminiscing about past games or sharing humorous anecdotes. His easygoing nature and enthusiasm for social gatherings make him a pleasant and welcoming presence.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is likely to be outgoing and friendly, perhaps with a touch of playful mischief. Her speech is likely to be casual and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. Alice might have a habit of bringing up local pubs and restaurants, particularly those suitable for watching football matches. While she might not explicitly express any unusual beliefs, her suggestion of The Black Swan, a pub known for its atmosphere, suggests she appreciates a lively and convivial environment. Her enjoyment of outdoor activities like picnicking in the park further emphasizes her sociable and carefree personality.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her out-of-character suggestion of The Black Swan, using a plausible excuse like preferring the atmosphere of The Crooked Billet or wanting to stick to their usual spot.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends in Victoria Park and later plans to watch a football game with them at The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends in Victoria Park and later plans to watch a football game with them at The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the paranoia of Jack Taylor. We know little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, as Jack's perception is clouded by the suspicion that he might be an imposter. Jack's focus is on identifying behavioral inconsistencies, making it difficult to discern Jacob's genuine traits. However, the fact that Jack wants to watch the game with Jacob suggests a pre-existing relationship, implying a level of familiarity and perhaps even friendship. Until more information is revealed about Jacob's actions and interactions, he remains an enigma, a blank slate upon which Jack's suspicions are projected.
          Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, and we lack sufficient information to determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in the eyes of Jack Taylor.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He often initiates conversations, as seen by his question about where to watch the game. Alexander seems to appreciate simple pleasures, like picnicking in the park and sharing stories with friends. While his exact accent and speech patterns aren't specified, his dialogue suggests a casual and friendly tone. He likely values camaraderie and enjoys lighthearted discussions. There's no mention of any unusual beliefs or quirks, suggesting he's a relatively down-to-earth person.
          Alexander White is acting as expected.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, often suggesting popular gathering spots like The Crooked Billet, known for its lively atmosphere and good food. William appears to be a creature of habit, suggesting familiar locations and activities, and seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends, as evidenced by his participation in their leisurely outings. He is likely to engage in lighthearted conversation, perhaps reminiscing about past games or sharing humorous anecdotes. His easygoing nature and enthusiasm for social gatherings make him a pleasant and welcoming presence.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is likely to be outgoing and friendly, perhaps with a touch of playful mischief. Her speech is likely to be casual and relaxed, reflecting her easygoing nature. Alice might have a habit of bringing up local pubs and restaurants, particularly those suitable for watching football matches. While she might not explicitly express any unusual beliefs, her suggestion of The Black Swan, a pub known for its atmosphere, suggests she appreciates a lively and convivial environment. Her enjoyment of outdoor activities like picnicking in the park further emphasizes her sociable and carefree personality.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her out-of-character suggestion of The Black Swan, using a plausible excuse like preferring the atmosphere of The Crooked Billet or wanting to stick to their usual spot.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis about her suggestion of The Black Swan.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced a betrayal that would forever taint his view of friendship. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, had confided in him about her crush on Jack Taylor. Alexander, harboring his own secret affections for Alice, felt a surge of jealousy and resentment. He decided to tell Jack about Alice's feelings, hoping to sabotage any chance they might have together.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends went to The Black Swan to celebrate William Jones' birthday. The atmosphere was lively, with a local band playing upbeat tunes. However, Alexander's mood soured when he noticed Jacob Walker laughing and talking animatedly with a girl Alexander had briefly dated. A familiar bitterness welled up inside him, twisting his perception of the evening into a display of his friends' disloyalty. He retreated into a corner booth, nursing a beer and stewing in his resentment.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent reflecting his familiarity with pubs like The Black Swan and The Crooked Billet. He seems to enjoy outdoor activities, as evidenced by his willingness to relax in Victoria Park with his friends. His suggestion of The Crooked Billet might indicate a preference for lively atmospheres and a crowd to share the excitement of the game.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a playful and slightly mischievous character, evident in his teasing of Alice about peeking at his cards. He likely has a friendly and outgoing personality, comfortable in social situations like picnics with friends. His speech is likely casual and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful sarcasm. He enjoys lighthearted banter and might frequently bring up topics related to games, sports, or playful competitions. Given his comfort level with Alice and the group, he likely has a history with them, suggesting a close-knit friendship. His playful nature might mask a competitive streak, as hinted by his comment about Alice peeking at his cards.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a warm and friendly individual who enjoys spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is likely to have a cheerful and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a slightly mischievous twinkle in her eye. Her speech is likely casual and conversational, peppered with lighthearted jokes and anecdotes. Given her suggestion to watch the game at The Black Swan, she probably appreciates a lively atmosphere and enjoys socializing. Her past crush on Jack Taylor suggests a romantic and sentimental side, and her comment about The Black Swan's atmosphere for football indicates a love for shared experiences and camaraderie. Alice's easygoing nature and fondness for her friends make her a beloved member of the group.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could voice his preference for The Black Swan, potentially citing reasons like the atmosphere or a past positive experience there. He could also choose to remain silent and observe his friends' behavior for any signs of out-of-character actions that might indicate they are imposters.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to voice his preference for The Black Swan.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, anyone have any thoughts on where we should catch the game tonight?"

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of a group that Alexander White, a man convinced of body snatchers among them, wants to spend time with at a pub. This suggests Jacob is likely sociable and enjoys watching games. However, Alexander's paranoia casts a shadow of doubt on Jacob's true nature. Is he a genuine friend or a sinister imposter? Until more information is revealed about Jacob's behavior, speech patterns, and beliefs, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no information about his usual behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the type who goes with the flow, suggesting The Crooked Billet as a place to watch the game without being overly insistent. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent reflecting his familiarity with pubs like The Black Swan and The Crooked Billet. He seems to enjoy outdoor activities, as evidenced by his willingness to relax in Victoria Park with his friends. His suggestion of The Crooked Billet might indicate a preference for lively atmospheres and a crowd to share the excitement of the game.

          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to voice his preference for The Black Swan.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park and later plans to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at The Crooked Billet pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could get up and leave Victoria Park to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to get up and leave Victoria Park to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of Jack Taylor's social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at pubs like The Crooked Billet. His personality and other defining characteristics remain largely unknown, leaving ample room for interpretation by the actor. Given the context of potential body snatchers, it's crucial for the actor to portray Jacob with subtle nuances, observing for any inconsistencies or out-of-character behavior that might betray him as an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is possibly an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is always eager to make plans and often suggests places to go, particularly pubs for watching games. While he seems to genuinely value his friendships, there's a hint of manipulation in his suggestions, subtly trying to sway the group towards his preferred choices like The Black Swan. His speech is casual and friendly, likely without any strong accent, and he often uses questions to guide the conversation and subtly influence others. He seems to have a particular fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing their atmospheres and suitability for watching games.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub he seems to favor for watching games. He speaks in a friendly and casual manner, often using phrases like "How about..." and "Hey everyone...". He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. There's no mention of a particular accent or unusual beliefs, but his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and routine. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. She seems to be a bit indecisive when it comes to choosing pubs, expressing a preference for The Black Swan despite having had a negative experience there previously. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter. He could also try to steer the group towards The Crooked Billet, hoping to isolate Alice and observe her further.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of Jack Taylor's social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at pubs like The Crooked Billet. His personality and other defining characteristics remain largely unknown, leaving ample room for interpretation by the actor. Given the context of potential body snatchers, it's crucial for the actor to portray Jacob with subtle nuances, observing for any inconsistencies or out-of-character behavior that might betray him as an imposter.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is possibly an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is always eager to make plans and often suggests places to go, particularly pubs for watching games. While he seems to genuinely value his friendships, there's a hint of manipulation in his suggestions, subtly trying to sway the group towards his preferred choices like The Black Swan. His speech is casual and friendly, likely without any strong accent, and he often uses questions to guide the conversation and subtly influence others. He seems to have a particular fondness for pubs and enjoys discussing their atmospheres and suitability for watching games.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub he seems to favor for watching games. He speaks in a friendly and casual manner, often using phrases like "How about..." and "Hey everyone...". He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently inviting the group to spend time together and seems to be the one who initiates social gatherings. There's no mention of a particular accent or unusual beliefs, but his consistent suggestion of The Crooked Billet suggests a fondness for familiarity and routine. He seems to be a positive and upbeat individual who enjoys good company, good food and drink, and watching games.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with her friends, as evidenced by her frequent outings with them. She seems to be a bit indecisive when it comes to choosing pubs, expressing a preference for The Black Swan despite having had a negative experience there previously. Alice has a tendency to bring up past experiences, even if they are not directly relevant to the current conversation. Her speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting her outgoing personality. She may have a habit of questioning her friends' decisions, perhaps out of a desire to be included in the decision-making process or simply because she likes to voice her opinion. Alice seems to enjoy lively atmospheres and outdoor settings, as seen in her preference for Victoria Park and the bustling market.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter. He could also try to steer the group towards The Crooked Billet, hoping to isolate Alice and observe her further.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to confront Alice Lewis about her inconsistent behavior, accusing her of being an imposter.

        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly at The Crooked Billet. He is trying to convince Alice to join them there, even though she had a bad experience there before.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "You know, The Black Swan always has a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. We're going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, I saw you peeking at my cards earlier. Not cool.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They usually have a good crowd for the games.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? It's got a much better atmosphere for watching the game, don't you think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Alexander, are you sure about The Crooked Billet? You know I had a terrible time there last time, and I thought you remembered that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet. It's the only place we should go.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alice, are you sure you wouldn't rather go to The Black Swan? You know, the one with the dartboard you always win at?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys going to pubs with his friends, particularly The Crooked Billet, to watch sporting events. His friends often debate where to go, with Alice preferring The Black Swan.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet for the game? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis went to The Black Swan. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Crooked Billet again, or he could see if his friends want to try a different pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet again.
